aws::graph::propositions: # Aviation Accident Report for Kitfox Super Sport N960WM in Twin Bridges, Montana
The accident occurred in Twin Bridges, Montana.
The accident occurred on October 18, 2012, at 14:40 local time.
The aircraft involved was an Albright Stan Kitfox Super Sport.
The defining event was loss of control in flight.
The flight was conducted under Part 91: General aviation - Personal.
The accident number was WPR13CA018.
The aircraft registration was N960WM.
The aircraft sustained substantial damage.
There were no injuries to the sole occupant.
The pilot attempted to perform a full-flap soft-field takeoff in the experimental light sport airplane.
The pilot had flown about 16 hours in the accident airplane.
The pilot purchased the airplane from the airplane builder 4 months before the accident.
This was the pilot's first attempt at full-flap soft-field takeoff in this airplane.
The airplane rolled abruptly to the right as it left the ground.
The right wing tip struck the ground.
The airplane cartwheeled.
The airplane came to rest pointing in the opposite direction of intended travel.
The right wing and fuselage were substantially damaged.
Postaccident examination revealed that the airplane's flaperons were misrigged.
The difference in flaperon deflection was more extreme in the full flap position.
In the full flap position with a full left control deflection input, the right flaperon moved 3 degrees more than properly rigged.
In the full flap position with a full left control deflection input, the left flaperon moved 3 degrees less than properly rigged.
The asymmetric nature of the flaperon deflections induced an adverse yaw to the right.
The adverse yaw occurred despite the pilot's corrective control inputs.
The airplane builder performed the most recent annual airworthiness inspection 4 1/2 months before the accident.
The National Transportation Safety Board determined the probable cause of this accident to be the airplane builder's failure to rig the flight controls correctly.
The incorrectly rigged flight controls resulted in a loss of control after takeoff.

text:
# Aviation Investigation Final Report

## Location:
Twin Bridges, Montana

## Date & Time: 
October 18, 2012, 14:40 Local

## Aircraft:
ALBRIGHT STAN KITFOX SUPER SPORT

## Defining Event:
Loss of control in flight

## Flight Conducted Under:
Part 91: General aviation - Personal

## Accident Number:
WPR13CA018

## Registration:
N960WM

## Aircraft Damage:
Substantial

## Injuries:
1 None

## Analysis

The pilot attempted to perform a full-flap soft-field takeoff in the experimental light sport airplane. The pilot had flown about 16 hours in the accident airplane in the 4 months since he purchased it from the airplane builder; however, this was his first attempt at full-flap soft-field takeoff in this airplane. As the airplane left the ground, it rolled abruptly to the right. The right wing tip struck the ground, and the airplane cartwheeled, coming to rest pointing in the opposite direction of intended travel. The right wing and fuselage were substantially damaged.

Postaccident examination revealed that the airplane's flaperons were misrigged and that the resultant difference in flaperon deflection was more extreme in the full flap position. In the full flap position with a full left control deflection input, the right flaperon moved 3 degrees more and the left flaperon 3 degrees less than they would have if properly rigged. The asymmetric nature of the flaperon deflections induced an adverse yaw to the right despite the pilot's corrective control inputs. Examination of the airplane maintenance logbook revealed that the airplane builder performed the most recent annual airworthiness inspection 4 1/2 months before the accident.

## Probable Cause and Findings

The National Transportation Safety Board determines the probable cause(s) of this accident to be:
The airplane builder's failure to rig the flight controls correctly, which resulted in a loss of control after takeoff.

---
